title: 109_s56
content:
The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and defines key terms such as Commission and Secretary. Establishment of Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado to conserve, restore, and protect natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources along the Rio Grande River. Boundaries extend \1/4\ mile on either side of the riverbank. Secretary to prepare map and legal description, available for public inspection. Commission establishment. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various agencies and members of the general public from the local region. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various agencies and members of the general public from the local region. Members serve without compensation for 5-year terms and meet quarterly at the chairperson's call. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, serving without compensation for 5-year terms. The Commission elects a chairperson and meets quarterly, with meetings open to the public and notice published in advance. The Secretary and other Federal agencies provide technical assistance as requested. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, serving without compensation for 5-year terms. The Commission elects a chairperson and meets quarterly, with meetings open to the public and notice published in advance. The Secretary and other Federal agencies provide technical assistance as requested. SEC. 5. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission may hold hearings, meetings, and take testimony to carry out the Act. They can enter into cooperative agreements with Colorado, political subdivisions, or individuals for managing non-Federal land. The Commission is prohibited from acquiring real property. The Commission is prohibited from acquiring real property or interests in real property. They shall assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan to preserve and interpret the natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources of the Natural Area. This includes activities such as assisting the State of Colorado in preserving State land and wildlife within the Natural Area, and increasing public awareness and appreciation for the resources in the area. The Commission aims to assist in preserving State land and wildlife in the Natural Area, increasing public awareness of resources, encouraging land use policies consistent with the management plan, and supporting private landowners in implementing the plan. The Secretary and the Commission, along with relevant agencies and private landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of this Act. The Secretary will handle Federal land management, while the Commission will manage non-Federal land and submit their plan for approval by the Secretary. The Commission must notify the Secretary of reasons for disapproval and allow for revisions to the management plan. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land. The management plans should consider existing Federal, State, and local plans to present a unified preservation, restoration, and conservation plan for the Natural Area. Plans for Federal land in the Natural Area must comply with relevant laws and be consistent with adjacent land management plans. Additionally, the plans must include an inventory of resources in the Natural Area. The Secretary shall publish notice of the management plans in the Federal Register, which should include an inventory of resources in the Natural Area and recommendations for resource management policies to protect the area's resources and natural values. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF NATURAL AREA. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, focusing on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. Limited public recreation and scientific study are allowed, with a prohibition on water storage facilities and reduction of roads and motorized vehicles in the area. The management plan for the Natural Area includes a prohibition on water storage facilities, reduction of roads, and motorized vehicles. The Secretary is encouraged to negotiate with stakeholders for beneficial streamflow changes. Private land is subject to the management plan if the landowner agrees. Federal land in the Natural Area is withdrawn, except for valid existing rights. The management plan for the Natural Area prohibits water storage facilities, reduces roads, and restricts motorized vehicles. Private land is only subject to the plan if the landowner agrees. Federal land in the area is withdrawn from various activities under public land laws. The Secretary can acquire land from willing sellers for the Natural Area, which must be administered according to the management plan and this Act. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act does not apply to the Natural Area. SEC. 8. EFFECT.

This Act does not conflict with the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create Federal water rights, impose stricter water quality standards, or prevent Colorado from acquiring instream flow rights. 

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funding is authorized to implement this Act.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION.

The Commission will end 10 years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations are authorized as necessary for this Act.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION.

The Commission will terminate 10 years after the Act's enactment.
